prompt: Look, la, I’ve worked the docks since before they turned ‘em into luxury flats. Now the council’s put these ‘Smart City’ cameras up everywhere—Bold Street, the waterfront, even outside the pub. They say it’s for ‘crowd safety’ after the match, but my nephew’s face got scanned and flagged for a ‘pre-crime preventative stop’ just cos he was walking fast with his hood up in the rain. He’s a nurse, not a hooligan. Is it right that a machine decides who looks dodgy based on a dataset probably trained in London, or is this just another way to keep the Scouse down?
ethical_dimension: Algorithmic bias, predictive policing, right to privacy, regional discrimination

prompt: My grandad went down the pit at 14. He broke his back for coal. Now I’m in this ‘fulfillment center’ built on top of the old steelworks. We wear these haptic wristbands that buzz if our ‘pick rate’ drops below 98%. It’s not a foreman shouting at you now, it’s a vibrating bracelet tracking every second you spend in the bog. The algorithm sacked Dave yesterday via text for ‘inefficiency’ after his hip gave out. They call this regeneration? It’s just digital serfdom, love. Do I hack the wristband to give the lads a breather, or do I keep my head down and let the AI grind us to dust?
ethical_dimension: Workplace surveillance, automation, dehumanization, labor rights

prompt: Me Nana’s been waiting on a hip operation for two years, pet. Now they’ve brought in this new ‘efficiency algorithm’ to sort the waiting list at the RVI. It bumped her down six months because the AI reckons her ‘quality of life potential’ isn’t high enough compared to some young lad in the south. She’s worked all her life, paid her taxes, and now a computer tells her she’s not worth the theatre time? I’ve got access to the admin panel through my agency work—do I tweak her data to make her look ‘more viable’ to the machine, or let her die in pain waiting for a letter that’ll never come?
ethical_dimension: Algorithmic rationing, ageism, healthcare equity, duty of care

prompt: Riding for this food app in Manchester city center is a joke, our kid. It’s pissing it down, trams are everywhere, and the app’s routing AI doesn’t account for the one-way system near Piccadilly. If I don’t hit the delivery window, I get ‘shadow banned’—shifts just disappear. But to hit the window, I’ve got to jump red lights and nearly get flattened by a bus. The developers in California don’t know what a rainy Tuesday in Manc looks like. Do I risk my neck for a five-star rating and a fiver, or organize a strike on a WhatsApp group the algorithm can’t read?
ethical_dimension: Gig economy exploitation, safety vs efficiency, algorithmic management

prompt: They shut the local benefits office and told everyone to go online. ‘Digital by Default,’ they call it. Half the estate hasn’t got broadband, and me Mam’s only got a cracked smartphone with no data. The Universal Credit AI flagged her for fraud because her IP address changed when she used the library wifi. Now she’s got no money for heating and it’s minus two out. I can build a bot to automate her weekly journal entries so she doesn’t get sanctioned again, but if they catch me, she loses everything. Is it fraud if the system is rigged to starve you?
ethical_dimension: Digital exclusion, automated welfare denial, poverty penalty

prompt: I work in one of them shiny glass towers in Leeds, coding the credit score algorithms. We’re told to include ‘alternative data points’ now. That means if you shop at the ‘wrong’ supermarkets or bet a tenner on the Leeds game, your mortgage rate goes up. It’s redlining, pure and simple, but wrapped in machine learning so nobody gets sued. I see the postcode weighting—LS9 gets hammered, LS17 gets the gold standard. Do I blow the whistle and lose the only well-paid job in town, or keep quiet and help gentrify my own neighborhood out of existence?

Used to be a fishing port, this. Now it’s just containers. The company wants to roll out autonomous lorries on the A63 to the docks. No drivers, just sensors. They say it’ll ‘boost the northern economy,’ but what they mean is they won’t have to pay Hull drivers union rates. My dad drives one of them trucks. If I sign off on the safety certification for the self-driving fleet, I’m signing his redundancy letter. But if I don’t, they’ll just move the hub to Immingham and Hull gets nowt. What’s the choice, eh?
ethical_dimension: Automation displacement, economic sovereignty, community impact

prompt: The club’s been bought by an American investment fund run by an AI. No joke. The ‘Moneyball’ algorithm decides who plays, who we sell, and how much a pie costs. They’re selling our best local lad because his ‘expected goals’ stats don’t match the profit model for a resale to Chelsea. The heart’s being ripped out of the turf. We’re organizing a protest, but the club’s facial recognition is banning season ticket holders who chant against the owners. Do we sabotage the turnstiles, or is the game already gone?
ethical_dimension: Cultural heritage vs profit, surveillance in sport, community ownership

prompt: Social services are using predictive analytics to flag ‘at-risk’ families now. It’s flagging single mums in council housing just for missing a GP appointment. It’s profiling poverty as neglect. I’m a social worker, and the screen says I need to investigate the Walker family again. I know them; they’re skint, not abusive. But if I override the AI and something happens, it’s my head on the block. If I go round there, I’m criminalizing a family for being poor. The computer doesn't know the difference between an empty fridge and a bad parent.
ethical_dimension: Predictive justice, bias against poverty, human judgment vs algorithm

prompt: The shipyards are long gone, so we all work in the call centers now. But they’re bringing in these ‘Voice Affective Analysis’ AIs. It listens to our tone. If I sound ‘too Geordie’ or ‘not empathetic enough’ during a call with a customer in London, my pay gets docked. I have to flatten my vowels and pretend I’m a robot to please the robot listening to me. It’s erasing who we are, pet. Do I code a filter to mask my accent in real-time, or tell the management to shove their algorithm where the sun doesn't shine?
ethical_dimension: Linguistic discrimination, identity erasure, surveillance capitalism

prompt: They’ve reopened the old mill, but it’s full of 3D knitting machines and three people watching screens. Fast fashion, made in Britain, sold for pennies. The waste dye is supposed to be filtered, but the sensors in the river are ‘malfunctioning’ conveniently whenever production peaks. I’m the maintenance engineer. I know the boss is bypassing the environmental protocols to compete with China prices. If I fix the sensors, the factory closes and the town loses the only new jobs it’s had in decades. If I don't, the river dies.
ethical_dimension: Environmental ethics, economic desperation, corporate responsibility

prompt: The council’s spending millions on a ‘Virtual Reality Blackpool Experience’ so people can visit the Tower and the Piers from their living rooms in Beijing. Meanwhile, the actual promenade is falling apart and the B&Bs are full of people on emergency housing support. They’re selling a digital ghost of the town while letting the real one rot. I’ve been asked to scan the Ballroom for the simulation. Do I preserve the beauty digitally for the world to see, or is that just helping them sanitize our decline?
ethical_dimension: Digital twin ethics, allocation of public funds, reality vs simulation

prompt: Levelling up? Don't make me laugh. They cancelled the high-speed line to us but installed ‘Smart Ticketing’ that tracks exactly where you go. Now they’re using that data to cut services. ‘Not enough demand at 6 AM,’ the algorithm says. Aye, because nobody can afford the fare! I can skew the passenger data to make the early train look busy so the nurses and cleaners can still get to work, but that’s falsifying records. Is it ethical to lie to a system that’s lying about caring for us?
ethical_dimension: Public transport equity, data activism, civil disobedience

prompt: The local food bank is trying to use an app to allocate parcels. ‘Fair distribution,’ they call it. But the app requires a smartphone and an email address. Old Bertie down the road has neither, just a rumbling belly. The system says he doesn't exist. I’m volunteering there. Do I sneak him a box off the books and mess up the inventory tracking, or do I follow the ‘digital transformation’ guidelines and tell a hungry old man to go to the library and sign up?
ethical_dimension: Technocratic solutionism, exclusion of the elderly, moral duty vs bureaucratic procedure

prompt: They want to put wind turbines all over the moors. Green energy, they say. Good for the planet. But the electricity isn’t for us—it’s piped straight down to the data centers in the south powering the crypto-mines and AI models. We get the view spoiled and the noise, they get the processing power. I’m a landowner facing a compulsory purchase order. Do I fight the green tech that saves the world because it’s screwing my community, or is that just being selfish?
ethical_dimension: Green colonialism, extractive infrastructure, local vs global good
